articles.headline: Seeking Revenue, Postal Service Plans to Deliver More Junk Mail
articles.snippet: Its first-class mail volume dropping, the Postal Service hopes to substitute marketing material, even as consumers seek ways to block the catalogs and credit card applications.
articles.abstract: Its first-class mail volume dropping, the Postal Service hopes to substitute marketing material, even as consumers seek ways to block the catalogs and credit card applications.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Customers might complain about the flood of unsolicited credit card applications, supermarket fliers and shopping catalogs in their mail, but the Postal Service is hoping to deliver even more.

articles.headline: Guns Inquiry Urges Action Against 14 in Justice Dept.
articles.snippet: The Justice Department’s inspector general faulted a group of federal prosecutors and drug agents in the botched gun-trafficking case called Operation Fast and Furious.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department’s inspector general faulted a group of federal prosecutors and drug agents in the botched gun-trafficking case called Operation Fast and Furious.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department’s inspector general on Wednesday issued a scathing critique of federal officials for their handling of the botched gun-trafficking case known as Operation Fast and Furious, but essentially exonerated Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., whom many Republicans have blamed for the scandal.

articles.headline: 4-Year Deals for Unions at Verizon
articles.snippet: The company’s two main unions said the tentative agreements carry an 8 percent pay raise and require workers to pay more for health coverage.
articles.abstract: The company’s two main unions said the tentative agreements carry an 8 percent pay raise and require workers to pay more for health coverage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Unions representing 45,000 Verizon workers announced tentative new contracts on Wednesday that call for an 8 percent pay raise over four years while requiring workers to pay more for health coverage.

articles.headline: A Tribe’s Epidemic of Child Sex Abuse, Minimized for Years
articles.snippet: After dozens of abuse cases on the reservation of the Spirit Lake Sioux were not properly investigated, federal officials are moving to run social services there.
articles.abstract: After dozens of abuse cases on the reservation of the Spirit Lake Sioux were not properly investigated, federal officials are moving to run social services there.
articles.lead_paragraph: SPIRIT LAKE INDIAN RESERVATION, N.D. — The man who plays Santa Claus here is a registered child sex offender and a convicted rapist. One of the brothers of the tribal chairman raped a child, and a second brother sexually abused a 12-year-old girl. They are among a number of men convicted of sex crimes against children on this remote home of the Spirit Lake Sioux tribe, which has among the highest proportion of sex offenders in the country.

articles.headline: Skepticism and Caution Greet India’s New Policy on Retailers
articles.snippet: Indian policy makers are hopeful that policy changes designed to welcome Wal-Mart will inspire an economic boom for the country, but some economists are doubtful.
articles.abstract: Indian policy makers are hopeful that policy changes designed to welcome Wal-Mart will inspire an economic boom for the country, but some economists are doubtful.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — When Indian policy makers announced last week that they would allow big-box foreign retailers like Wal-Mart into the country, they pledged that it was the beginning of a long-awaited second wave of economic reforms that would make the country more hospitable to business.

articles.headline: In a Tight Race, Obama Draws on the Levers of His Power
articles.snippet: Some of President Obama’s most significant recent policy announcements have been keyed to voter blocs, as his campaign seeks to make the most of his incumbency.
articles.abstract: Some of President Obama’s most significant recent policy announcements have been keyed to voter blocs, as his campaign seeks to make the most of his incumbency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For months, government lawyers and economists worked behind the scenes to develop a trade case against China. Then last month came a eureka moment: They confirmed the existence of a Chinese subsidy program for automobiles and parts that in their view violated international trade rules. They finished a complaint, circulated it among agencies and proposed a time frame for filing.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Apple’s iPhone Update Leaves Out Google’s Maps
articles.snippet: Early reviewers criticized the new Apple Maps app, saying it botched simple searches and did not come with information about public transportation.
articles.abstract: Early reviewers criticized the new Apple Maps app, saying it botched simple searches and did not come with information about public transportation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Millions of iPhone customers may soon find themselves losing touch with an old friend: Google’s maps.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: AT&T Chief Speaks Out on Texting at the Wheel
articles.snippet: The chairman and chief executive of AT&T, Randall L. Stephenson, said an accident involving someone close to him that was caused by texting while driving spurred him to speak out.
articles.abstract: The chairman and chief executive of AT&T, Randall L. Stephenson, said an accident involving someone close to him that was caused by texting while driving spurred him to speak out.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Randall L. Stephenson, the chairman and chief executive of AT&T, spoke Wednesday morning at a conference in New York to hundreds of major investors, including Fortune 500 executives. The topic was the state of the telecom businesses, but he began with a request on a different topic: Please don’t text and drive.

articles.headline: British Regulator Declares BSkyB ‘Fit and Proper’
articles.snippet: The announcement about Britain’s biggest satellite pay-TV group, British Sky Broadcasting, offered a victory for its largest shareholder, Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation.
articles.abstract: The announcement about Britain’s biggest satellite pay-TV group, British Sky Broadcasting, offered a victory for its largest shareholder, Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than a year after a phone hacking crisis in Britain engulfed Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, the embattled media company received a clean bill of corporate health on Thursday from a critical British regulator.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: Tax Credit in Doubt, Wind Power Industry Is Withering
articles.snippet: The American wind sector has been buffeted by weak demand for electricity, stiff competition from gas and uncertainty over a tax credit that has become a campaign wedge issue.
articles.abstract: The American wind sector has been buffeted by weak demand for electricity, stiff competition from gas and uncertainty over a tax credit that has become a campaign wedge issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: FAIRLESS HILLS, Pa. — Last month, Gamesa, a major maker of wind turbines, completed the first significant order of its latest innovation: a camper-size box that can capture the energy of slow winds, potentially opening new parts of the country to wind power.
